nameEntry.part: St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Girls' Orphanage Industrial School, Subiaco
Orphanage Industrial School for Roman Catholic Girls

biogHist.abstract: St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage was established in Subiaco in 1901. It was run by the Sisters of Mercy, for girls aged up to 16 years who were placed there by government authorities or who were private admissions. From 1947, child migrants from Britain and Malta were sent to St Joseph's. It closed in 1971 and became the Catherine McAuley Centre.
biogHist.p: The St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage was run by the Sisters of Mercy from 21 November 1901 on the site of the old boys' orphanage in Subiaco. The Sisters and children from the Roman Catholic Girls' Orphanage in Victoria Square moved to Subiaco a few months after the boys moved out to Clontarf. Although St Joseph's was called an orphanage, both children who were wards and those who were 'privately placed' lived there.

A letter of appreciation of the The Daily News Orphans' Christmas Cheer Fund in 1915 gives an insight into life at St Joseph's. The letter shows that donations enabled the children to occasionally have extras that were not part of their daily experience:

'The Sisters and children of the orphanage are extremely grateful for the donation [of &pound24]. Each child was provided with a portion of the money to spend as she wished, and nothing could exceed the pleasure thereby given, particularly as this year nothing was expected, owing to the heavy demands on our kind friends. A picnic was provided with the remainder which, as usual, delighted the children. Letter, 12 January 1916 published in The Daily News 2 December 1916, p.10'

Government reports (Signposts 2004, pp.454-455) show that there were 129 girls resident in 1920, with 114 girls in 1921. In subsequent years before World War II, the number of girls at St Joseph's ranged from 91 (in 1922) to 37 (in 1943). Reports from the 1920s and 1940s also report on the number of girls who were 'at service'. That is, working-age girls who were placed with employers (under a formal agreement) or who worked within the institution. Occasionally, reports show 'abscondings' or the number of children who ran away.

From 1947, child migrants from Britain and Malta were sent to St Joseph's. The government reports (Signposts pp.457-458) probably underestimate the number of girls in the Home during the period 1947 to 1956. From 1957, 'private admissions' (girls who were placed at St Joseph's by families or others) exceeded the number of girls placed by child welfare authorities. It is possible that girls admittedly privately were not counted in government reports in previous years.

In evidence to the Inquiry into Children in Institutional Care, later known as the 'Forgotten Australians' inquiry, a woman described (Forgotten Australians 2004, p.88), deprivations at St Joseph's that left a deep impression on her: 'We were never allowed to keep the presents as the nuns used to take them off us when we got back to the orphanage and would sell them at their fetes.'
Published, official, reports generally present a brighter picture.
In 1971, St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage closed and became the Catherine McAuley Centre.

chronItem.event: Location - St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage was located on a site that had originally been used for the Benedictine monastery in Subiaco

cpfRelation.relationEntry: St Vincent's Foundling Home (1914 - 1971)

descriptiveNote.p: St Joseph's Orphanage and St Vincent's Foundling Home were were close to each other at Subico. Younger children went to St Vincent's and older girls were housed at St Joseph's.

cpfRelation.relationEntry: Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association [CEMWA] (1947? - 1970)

descriptiveNote.p: The Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association was responsible for placing British and Maltese child migrants at St Joseph's Orphanage.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Ballet lesson

archref.abstract: 'Ballet lesson' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows girls in the hall at the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage. An approximate date range of 1920s to 1960s has been given, based on the girls' pinafores.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Table and chairs, St Joseph's Orphanage

archref.unittitle: Table and chairs, St Joseph's Orphanage
archref.abstract: The caption on this photograph says it shows the children's activity room of St Joseph's Girl's Orphanage in 1954. It is from the State Library of Western Australia's collection of online images that were made available by the Historical Records Rescue Consortium Project supported by Lotterywest.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: John Moss C.B.E. U.K. Child Welfare Expert. Visit to Australia. Part II

archref.unittitle: John Moss C.B.E. U.K. Child Welfare Expert. Visit to Australia. Part II
archref.abstract: This is a file held online by the National Archives of Australia. It has draft reports on the Australian institutions which took unaccompanied British child migrants after World War Two.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia

archref.unittitle: Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia
archref.abstract: 'Enquiry by Mr. John Moss. Points on which information is needed as to provision for the welfare of children emigrating from the United Kingdom to Australia' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. It is the questionnaire that was circulated to government, the organisations that received and placed child migrants, and the children's Homes where the children lived. This questionnaire was received by the Commonwealth Government on 10 May 1951.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: CEMWA Response to Moss Questionnaire

archref.abstract: 'CEMWA Response to Moss Questionnaire' is an excerpt from the digital copy of the Moss John - visiting Child Welfare Expert file from the National Archives of Australia website. There is an undated letter from the Catholic Episcopal Migration and Welfare Association Inc, responding to questions about Bindoon, Clontarf, Castledare,Nazareth House, St Joseph's Orphanage (including St Vincent's Foundling Home), and Tardun. There is also a letter, dated 14 August 1951, from the Under Secretary for Lands and Immigration passing on further information about staffing at those institutions.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: St Joseph's Guard of Honour Kings Park

archref.unittitle: St Joseph's Guard of Honour Kings Park
archref.abstract: 'St Joseph's Guard of Honour Kings Park' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows girls and a sister from the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage awaiting a royal procession, which may have been a visit by the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester (1934 and 1945).

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Guard of Honour Kings Park

archref.abstract: 'Guard of Honour Kings Park' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows girls from the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage awaiting a royal procession, which may have been a visit by the Duke and Duchess of Gloucester (1934 and 1945).

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Classroom

archref.abstract: 'Classroom' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows students in the St. Maria Goretti School at the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage. The school is known to have been on site in 1953.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Main building St Joseph's Roman Catholic Girls Orphanage Industrial School, 1906

archref.unittitle: Main building St Joseph's Roman Catholic Girls Orphanage Industrial School, 1906
archref.abstract: 'Main building St Joseph's Roman Catholic Girls Orphanage Industrial School, 1906' is a digital copy of an image included (after p.16) in the Report by the Superintendent of Public Charities and Inspector of Industrial and Reformatory Schools for the year ending 31 December 1906.
archref.note: Department for Child Protection and Family Support

resourceRelation.relationEntry: St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage

archref.abstract: This is a digital copy of a photograph of the front entrance of St Joseph's Girl's Orphanage in 1953. It is from the State Library of Western Australia's collection of online images that were made available by the Historical Records Rescue Consortium Project supported by Lotterywest.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Sing song

archref.abstract: 'Sing song' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows girls gathered around a piano in the hall at the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage. An approximate date range of 1920s to 1960s has been given, based on the girls' uniforms.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Girls' dormitory

archref.abstract: 'Girls' dormitory is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows a dormitory at the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage. An approximate date range of 1920s to 1960s has been given, based on the style of the furniture.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Dancing classes 5

archref.abstract: 'Dancing classes 5' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows girls at a dress rehearsal in the hall at the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage. An approximate date range of 1920s to 1960s has been given.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Gardening St Joseph's 5

archref.abstract: 'Gardening St Joseph's 5' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows girls working in the garden at the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage. An approximate date range of 1920s to 1960s has been given, based on the girls' pinafores.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Back of St Joseph's main building

archref.unittitle: Back of St Joseph's main building
archref.abstract: 'Back of St Joseph's main building' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows two girls on a see-saw and some sisters. An approximate date range of 1920 to 1960s has been given, based on the children's clothing.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: St Joseph's Front

archref.abstract: 'St Joseph's Front' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. An approximate date range of 1930 to 1950s has been given, based on the car in the image.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Early photo

archref.abstract: 'Early photo' is a digital copy of a photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows the Benedictine Monastery which became the Subiaco Boys' Orphanage (1872-1901) and then the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage (1901-1971). The image dates from 1859.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Back area - colour

archref.abstract: 'Back area - colour' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. According to information from the Mercy Heritage Centre, the St Maria Goretti classrooms were built in the lower area that is showing in the image. As it is a colour photograph, it is likely that the image dates from the 1940s or later.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Orphanage dining room

archref.abstract: 'Orphanage dining room' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows the dining room at the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage. An approximate date range of 1901-1950s has been given, based on the furnishings.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: Dormitory 1

archref.abstract: 'Dormitory 1' is a digital copy of an undated photograph from the Mercy Heritage Centre Collection of Images. It shows a dormitory at the St Joseph's Girls' Orphanage. An approximate date range of 1920s to 1960s has been given, based on the style of the dolls on the beds. It is possible that the picture was taken when the dormitory was decorated for a special event.

resourceRelation.relationEntry: St Joseph's Roman Catholic Girls Orphanage Industrial School, 1906

archref.unittitle: St Joseph's Roman Catholic Girls Orphanage Industrial School, 1906
archref.abstract: 'St Joseph's Roman Catholic Girls Orphanage Industrial School, 1906' is a digital copy of an image included (after p.16) in the Report by the Superintendent of Public Charities and Inspector of Industrial and Reformatory Schools for the year ending 31 December 1906.
archref.note: Department for Child Protection and Family Support
